Imminent additional NATO troop commitments removes incentive to convene a loya jirga.  Ghani has also been active consolidating his power base and marginalizing Abdullah, political priorities which supersede NUG-precepts for loya jirga.  Loya jirga will convene in 2018 at the earliest.

President Ghani seems like a man who likes be in control and most calls in the country for a loya jirga revolve around decentralizing power, and also peace plans but that's secondary here. I don't think he, or his allies, wants to call a loya jirga as an important part of the process would be formalizing the role of Abdullah Abdullah, the country's CEO (a long and somewhat ridiculous story behind that idea).

The patterns of Afghani tribes are very unpredictable.  The loya jirga conventions have no set format, frequency and the votes among the tribal elders are influenced by old tribal relationships that date back centuries.  The most recent loya jirga had 2,500 tribal elders in 2013.  The previous had 1,600 in 2010.  That is a huge change in the number of tribal seats in a three year period.  The power structure among that many small clusters of people is immeasurable.  Predicting the tribes of Afghanistan is a legitimate coin toss.
